message.content:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: You can use Mockito's Answer interface to dynamically return different values from your mock. Here's an example of how you can modify your CSVReaderMock class to achieve this:

import au.com.bytecode.opencsv.CSVReader;
import com.sun.javafx.beans.annotations.NonNull;
import org.mockito.Mockito;
import org.mockito.stubbing.Answer;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.LinkedList;
import java.util.List;

import static org.mockito.Mockito.mock;
import static org.mockito.Mockito.when;

public class CSVReaderMock {
    CSVReader reader;
    private boolean linesCorrectInitialized;
    private List<String[]> returnValues;

    public CSVReaderMock() {
        reader = mock(CSVReader.class);
        returnValues = new ArrayList<>();
    }

    public CSVReaderMock returnLines(@NonNull List<String> lines) {
        // the last value has to be null
        lines.add(null);
        try {
            for (String line : lines) {
                String[] lineArr = null;
                if (line != null) {
                    lineArr = line.split(",");
                }
                returnValues.add(lineArr);
            }
            linesCorrectInitialized = true;
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
        return this;
    }

    public CSVReader create() {
        if (!linesCorrectInitialized) {
            throw new RuntimeException("lines are not initialized correctly");
        }
        when(reader.readNext()).thenAnswer((Answer<String[]>) invocation -> {
            if (returnValues.isEmpty()) {
                return null;
            }
            return returnValues.remove(0);
        });
        return reader;
    }
}

And here's an example of how you can use this modified CSVReaderMock class in your test case:

@Test
public void testImportLines() throws Exception {
    CSVReader reader;
    List<String> list = new LinkedList<>();
    list.add("some,lines,for,testing");
    reader = new CSVReaderMock().returnLines(list).create();
    System.out.println(reader.readNext()); // should return ["some","lines","for","testing"]
    System.out.println(reader.readNext()); // should return null
}

This modified CSVReaderMock class uses a List<String[]> to store the return values for each call to readNext(). The Answer interface is used to dynamically return the next value from the list each time readNext() is called.
